panels.visual: Marco's ringed hands pull at the wool fibers, testing for coarseness and length. His face shows practiced evaluation - not impressed, but not dismissive. The gesture is intimate, professional, the touch of a man who knows exactly what he's holding and what it's worth.
panels.dialogue: Marco: "Not bad. Not exceptional, but not bad. I'll give you twelve denari for the lot."

panels.visual: Giovanni's father stands across from Marco, his weathered face showing the conflict between pride and necessity. He knows the wool is worth more - twenty at least, probably twenty-five in Venice. But here, in this backwater, Marco is the only buyer. His shoulders slump slightly as he prepares to haggle a losing battle.
panels.narration: Giovanni's father knew it was worth twenty at least, probably twenty-five in a Venetian market. But here, in this backwater village with no other buyers for miles, twelve denari was better than nothing.

panels.visual: The handshake that seals the deal - Marco's soft, ringed hand clasping the farmer's calloused one. Giovanni's father accepts fourteen denari with the resignation of one who has lost this battle many times before. In the background, fifteen-year-old Giovanni watches with something burning in his eyes - anger, perhaps, or shame. The merchant notices the boy's expression.
panels.narration: He haggled half-heartedly, got the merchant up to fourteen, and accepted defeat with the resignation of one who has lost this battle many times before.
